newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedes want referendum on EMU - poll.
newsitem.headline: Swedes want referendum on EMU - poll.

text.p: A majority of Swedes want a referendum on the question of whether Sweden should join Europe's Economic and Monetary Union (EMU), a poll published on Sunday showed.

The survey by the Swedish Institute of Public Opinion Research (SIFO), published in the Gothenberg Post, found 57 percent of those questioned wanted a referendum with only 31 percent opposed to such a move.

Joining the EMU would require constitutional amendments, but one third of the members of the Swedish parliament can force a referendum on any constitutional change. The survey was the third poll in a week that emphasised how widespread Euroscepticism has become in Sweden.

A Europe-wide poll published early last week showed only 32 percent of Swedes were positive towards the European Union while almost 50 percent believed the country had lost out from EU membership. Sweden joined in January 1995.
This was the lowest level of any member country and well below the average of 53 percent.
An opinion poll published on Friday showed that even Swedes who support EU membership were against joining the EMU, which is due to come into force on January 1, 1999.

The poll, conducted by a Swedish research group for society and information studies (FSI), found only 18 percent of 1,137 Swedish EU-advocates saw anything positive in a common European currency. A total of 52 percent said this was a bad idea.
Sweden is one of the handful of EU members still not in Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism (ERM), which is viewed as the first step towards EMU membership. The others are Greece, Italy and Britain.
